questions.text: Consider f(x) = x^4 - 4x^3. Find all critical numbers and determine where f is increasing/decreasing.
Classify each critical number as a local maximum, local minimum, or neither. Justify using the first-derivative sign change.
Determine the intervals where f is concave up/down and find all inflection points.
Find the absolute minimum of f on [-1, 5]; report the x-value and f(x).

answers.text: f'(x) = 4x^3 - 12x^2 = 4x^2(x - 3). Critical numbers: x = 0, 3. Sign of f': (-\infty, 0): f' < 0 (decreasing); (0, 3): f' < 0 (decreasing); (3, \infty): f' > 0 (increasing).
At x = 3, f' changes from negative to positive \Rightarrow local minimum. At x = 0, f' = 0 but no sign change \Rightarrow neither max nor min (horizontal inflection).

f''(x) = 12x^2 - 24x = 12x(x - 2). Concave up on (-\infty, 0) \cup (2, \infty); concave down on (0, 2). Inflection points where f'' changes sign: x = 0 and x = 2. Points: (0, 0) and (2, f(2)) = (2, 16 - 32 = -16).
Evaluate at endpoints and criticals: f(-1) = 5, f(0) = 0, f(3) = -27, f(5) = 125. Absolute minimum is -27 at x = 3.
